source: Dodson et al. (2015) Montana machine rate guide; FX adjusted to CAD at 1.33 CAD/USD (2024 avg).
notes: Total cost ≈ CAD 198/SMH split 45/55 owning/operating; fuel scaled to CAD 1.80/L. FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 4 No. 23 (2003) Table 2 line-haul feller-buncher (flat 25 t+) proxy for BC leveling heads gives CAD 31.37/SMH at 10 000 h (2002 dollars); CPI 2002→2024 ≈1.56 ⇒ ≈CAD 48.9/SMH repair+maintenance allowance.

source: FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 1 No. 12 Appendix 1 (Timberjack 240 cable skidder, semi-mechanized thinning).
notes: Direct hourly costs include operator wages and fuel but exclude supervision/overhead. Sum of fixed (12.33 $/SMH) and variable + labour (63.28 $/SMH) from Appendix 1; utilisation 90% reflects integrated lop-and-scatter crew.

source: FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 1 No. 12 Appendix 1 (Valmet 646 shortwood forwarder, commercial thinning).
notes: Appendix 1 lists 18.85 $/SMH fixed cost and 20.73 $/SMH variable cost plus 25 $/SMH operator wages (total 45.73) for the Valmet 646 working 20 m trail spacing with 8 m³ payloads.

source: Dodson et al. (2015) harvester/processor class. Converted to CAD with diesel at CAD 1.80/L.
notes: Total ≈ CAD 200/SMH, 42% owning / 58% operating. FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 4 No. 23 (2003) Table 2 dangle-head processor (≤60 cm) class gives CAD 19.27/SMH at 10 000 h (2002 dollars); CPI 2002→2024 ≈1.56 ⇒ ≈CAD 30.1/SMH repair+maintenance allowance.

source: Dodson et al. (2015) stroke delimber class with CAD FX.
notes: Total ≈ CAD 213/SMH. FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 4 No. 23 (2003) Table 2 boom-mount delimber (≤65 cm) class gives CAD 17.71/SMH at 10 000 h (2002 dollars); CPI 2002→2024 ≈1.56 ⇒ ≈CAD 27.6/SMH repair+maintenance allowance.

source: Dodson et al. (2015) loader class; CAD FX 1.33.
notes: Total ≈ CAD 140/SMH. FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 4 No. 23 (2003) Table 2 line loader class standing in for log loaders gives CAD 39.96/SMH at 10 000 h (2002 dollars); CPI 2002→2024 ≈1.56 ⇒ ≈CAD 62.3/SMH repair+maintenance allowance.

source: FERIC TR-45 Appendix II (Cat 966C loader owning/operating split, Jan 1979) blended with TN-46 Barko 450 utilisation (79%); wages/fuel from Appendix II reflect IWA+30% fringe.
notes: Original Cat 966C loader cost: $57.17/SMH in 1979 CAD (ownership $19.88 + wage/fuel/maintenance $37.29). Barko-specific utilisation (0.79) and truck-wait penalty still follow TN-46; CPI helper inflates to target year.

source: FPInnovations TR-45 Appendix II (January 1979) machine-rate table.
notes: Cat 966C log loader equipped for truck loading; 10,000 h life, 5-year depreciation, wage $12.71/SMH, fuel $4.70/SMH, maintenance set equal to owning cost. No profit/risk margin.

source: FPInnovations TR-45 Appendix II (Clark 667 / JD 640 / JD 740 weighted average).
notes: Reported $53.47/PMH (January 1979 CAD); converted to SMH at 80% utilisation (≈$42.78/SMH) with wages $12.06/SMH, fuel $4.50/PMH, maintenance equal to owning cost. No profit/risk.

source: FPInnovations TR-45 Appendix II Caterpillar D7G with winch/blade.
notes: Total $58.52/SMH (January 1979 CAD) with wages $12.06/SMH, fuel $4.50/SMH, maintenance $20.48/SMH. No profit/risk margin.

source: Hartley & Han (2007) Vancouver Island grapple yarding study; costs converted to 2024 CAD (CPI/FX).
notes: Assumes total ≈ CAD 380/SMH; mobilisation covers yarder + backspar move. FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 4 No. 23 (2003) Table 2 yarding crane large class (covers swing/tower systems) gives CAD 43.63/SMH at 10 000 h (2002 dollars); CPI 2002→2024 ≈1.56 ⇒ ≈CAD 68.1/SMH repair+maintenance allowance.

source: FERIC TN-147 (1990) Appendix I machine-cost analysis (Madill 009 highlead yarder).
notes: Costs exclude supervision/overhead/interest; labour = 1989 IWA rates +35% benefits. Ownership bundles yarder depreciation/insurance; operating cost covers hooktender/rigging crew, fuel/lube, and backspar upkeep. Use for standing-skyline/tower corridors without motorized grapples.

source: FERIC TN-147 (1990) Appendix I machine-cost analysis (Madill 009 highlead yarder).
notes: Six-person crew (yarder engineer, hooktender, two chokersetters, utility, landing support). Costs exclude supervision/overhead/interest; labour = 1989 IWA wages +35% benefits. Use when selecting the TN147 grapple-yarder preset or skyline harvest systems that rely on Madill 009 highlead corridors.

source: FERIC TN-201 (1993) Skylead C40 cable yarder cost analysis (Model 16000 near Vernon, BC).
notes: Standing-skyline yarder with Mini-Maki carriage; costs exclude supervision/overhead/interest and bundle the hooktender/chokers, fuel/lube, and carrier upkeep. Use for Skylead C40 intermediate-support corridors (FNCY12/TN-201) until dedicated harvest systems land.

source: FERIC TN-157 (1991) Appendix II cost tables; CPI-adjusted to 2024 CAD.
notes: Ownership includes yarder + backspar interest, insurance, and depreciation; operating costs bundle rigging, rope, labour (operator + hooktender + utility), fuel/lube, and repair/maintenance (R=$60k/yr yarder + $10k/yr backspar). Total shift cost = $259/h + $31/h (1991 CAD) before CPI.

source: FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 5 No. 28 (2004) Madill 071 + Acme 200 Pow'-R Block skyline conversion.
notes: Standing skyline conversion of heli corridors (Madill 071 + Acme 200 Pow'-R Block). Costs exclude supervision/overhead/interest; labour = 2002 coastal IWA rates +40% benefits. Use when modelling ADV5N28 clearcut/shelterwood presets or `cable_running_adv5n28_*` harvest systems.

source: FERIC TN-157 (1991) Appendix II cost tables for Cypress 7280B swing yarder with Hitachi UH14 backspar.
notes: Standing running-skyline preset (trail spar + mobile backspar). Costs exclude supervision/overhead/interest; labour reflects 1991 coastal IWA rates +38% benefits. Use when modelling TN157 or `cable_running`/`cable_salvage_grapple` presets to pull the BC swing-yard skyline rental rate.

source: LeDoux (1984) Production rates and costs of cable yarding wood residue (USDA NE Research Paper).
notes: Shotgun skyline configuration (Skagit BU-94) from the Willamette/Mt. Hood residue trials. Hourly costs include labour, loader, carriage, and radios; profit/overhead excluded.

source: LeDoux (1984) Production rates and costs of cable yarding wood residue (USDA NE Research Paper).
notes: Same BU-94 yarder rigged in highlead; LeDoux assumed identical hourly costs for the alternate configuration (labour + loader + rigging).

source: LeDoux (1984) Production rates and costs of cable yarding wood residue (USDA NE Research Paper).
notes: Self-propelled Washington 208E slack skyline (Young-Stannes carriage). Hourly costs include yarder, loader, labour, radios; profit/overhead excluded.

source: LeDoux (1984) Production rates and costs of cable yarding wood residue (USDA NE Research Paper).
notes: Crawler-mounted Thunderbird TMY-45 running skyline with Danebo MSP carriage. Costs reflect nine-person crew + loader; no profit/overhead.

source: FERIC TN-173 (1991) Table 4 direct cost analysis (Ecologger case, Kedgwick NB).
notes: Ownership column represents the reported $196.52/PMH yarder total (labour, depreciation, fuel, repairs). Operating column captures the supporting D6 tailhold/skidder costs (49.81 + 6.34 $/PMH). Use for `ecologger_short_span` presets; figures exclude supervision/overhead/profit.

source: FERIC TN-173 (1991) Table 4 direct cost analysis (Gabriel prototype case, Stephenville NL).
notes: Single truck-mounted drumset with skid pan; total reported cost $94.51/PMH (no separate support gear). Use when the `gabriel_salvage` preset is selected; excludes supervision/overhead.

source: FERIC TN-173 (1991) Table 4 direct cost analysis (Christie yarder case, Brookfield NS).
notes: Two-person hot-yarding crew; ownership column is the $114.45/PMH yarder total, operating column bundles the swing skidder (49.81) plus chain-saw cost (3.31) that supported landing clearing. Excludes supervision/overhead.

source: FERIC TN-173 (1991) Table 4 direct cost analysis (Télétransporteur case, Montmorency Forest QC).
notes: Ownership column captures the $109.81/PMH self-propelled carriage total; operating column sums the skidder + excavator anchors (5.87 + 15.51) and chain-saw allowance (3.31). Use for `teletransporteur_hot_yard` presets; excludes supervision/overhead.

source: FERIC TN-173 (1991) Table 4 direct cost analysis; Timbermaster data from the 1984–85 Rexfor trials.
notes: Trailer-mounted tower working downhill with shared swing skidder. Ownership column = $164.83/PMH yarder total (crew, depreciation, fuel); operating column = $43.76/PMH swing skidder support. Use when modelling `timbermaster_patch_cut` presets; excludes supervision/overhead.

source: FERIC FNG73 Field Note (1999) prototype; ownership/operating split derived from CAD 50–60k truck attachment cost, single-operator wage (1999 BC IWA +35% benefits), diesel @0.65 CAD/L, and light-maintenance allowance.
notes: Ownership reflects a CAD 60k attachment amortized over 5 years/1,200 SMH with 10% salvage plus 8% interest/insurance (≈11.5 $/SMH). Operating bundles one operator using the June 15, 1999 IWA log-truck/yarder-driver wage (24.01 $/h +38% benefits = 33.13 $/SMH per ADV2N62 Appendix II), diesel (8 L/h × 0.65 $/L ≈5.2 $/SMH), and a 16 $/SMH allowance for tires/hydraulics/rigging. Move-in cost assumes a short lowbed haul for the truck-mounted attachment.

source: Sessions & Boston (2006) shovel logging cost example + Dodson excavator rates (CAD FX).
notes: Total ≈ CAD 160/SMH. FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 4 No. 23 (2003) Table 2 30-ton excavator/loader class as shovel logger proxy gives CAD 20.52/SMH at 10 000 h (2002 dollars); CPI 2002→2024 ≈1.56 ⇒ ≈CAD 32.0/SMH repair+maintenance allowance.

source: Dodson et al. (2015) support equipment. Converted to CAD.
notes: Used for road touch-up/mobilization; lower utilisation (0.6) reflects intermittent use.
